intro: Muscari massayanum, commonly known as the Persian squill, is a bulbous plant native to the mountainous regions of central Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its dense clusters of bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 20–30 cm and features strap-like, grassy leaves. It thrives in well-drained soil and prefers full sun to partial shade. Muscari massayanum is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and rockeries.
